awd_titl_txt: Modulation of the Adrenocortical Response to Perturbations of the Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Extreme weather events such as storms, are increasing in frequency, duration and intensity. Couple this with other global changes resulting from human disturbance and it is clear that mechanisms underlying organism-environment interactions in response to stressful environmental factors are key. These responses, often called the "stress response" help the animal cope through the modification of physiology and behaviour that promote survival. The focus here will be on the stress hormone responses, particularly from the adrenal gland, that are a highly adaptive suite of physiological and behavioral traits that are conserved across vertebrates including humans. A basic understanding of how seasonal modulations of the stress response works will allow us to predict how vertebrate organisms adjust their physiology and behaviour in response to an increasingly capricious environment as well as across a species' range with an emphasis on those populations that are on the limits of, or have pushed beyond, their geographic range.  The PIs aim to educate K-12 students and teachers, while also reaching out to under-represented minorities (particularly Latinos in California) to enhance awareness, and conservation, of habitat for all organisms as well as birds. In these ways the work can be broadly disseminated to the public at large. In an era of dramatic environmental change, public awareness is critical and the broader impact activities will have far reaching influence. 

Mechanisms underlying organism-environment interactions in response to perturbations of the environment are key for survival. The focus here will be on the hormonal response, particularly corticosteroids from the adrenal gland. The PIs have a good understanding of the responses to environmental stress in biomedical contexts, often under the chronic stress paradigm. However, these approaches do not mimic nature in which organisms experience seasonal cycles in environmental conditions and the stress response is modulated accordingly. Understanding how individuals push the boundaries of their coping strategies as well as geographic range is critical both from a basic science standpoint and for conservation. The proposed work will assess how the adrenocortical stress response is regulated using both laboratory and field studies to inform us of what brain centers are responsible for controlling seasonal fluctuation in the stress response. In addition, the focus will be on how the activity of these brain regions fluctuates across the annual cycle of environmental severity, and also across a species' range with an emphasis on those populations that are on the limits of, or have pushed beyond, their geographic range. A basic understanding of how the HPA axis works in species that undergo seasonal modulations in the stress response will also allow the PIs to predict how vertebrate organisms adjust their physiology and behavior in response to an increasingly capricious environment.

Modulation of the adrenocortical response to perturbations of the environment.

Award number IOS-1558049. P.I. John C. Wingfield. Project Outcomes Report.

Intellectual Merit. In spring, millions of migrant birds stream north of the Arctic Circle to settle on the tundra and breed. They display and sing despite severe weather, reproduce quickly during the ephemeral summer, and then migrate south to avoid the arctic winter. Near Toolik Lake, Alaska, snow may melt from the tundra as early as the first week in May, but subsequent storms and temperatures down to -20°C may inundate early migrants. In other years, snow and sub-freezing temperatures may persist into late May and at any time during the summer and early autumn, posing further problems for nesting, molt, and preparations for departure to the south. Our research indicates that hormone-behavior adaptations have evolved in arctic breeding birds to cope with unpredictable weather, trophic resources and predator numbers, all of which vary with location in the Arctic and from year to year. This biological spectacle appears at first to be a frantic rush into a challenging environment. Closer observation and experiments reveal, however, a highly coordinated process with morphological, physiological and behavioral adaptations that permit great phenotypic flexibility to cope with the arctic weather. Polar regions are undergoing some of the fastest rates of change, particularly warming, on Earth. Distributions of plants are changing often involving the spread of shrub-like habitat into formerly open tundra. As a result the extents of arctic songbird breeding ranges are also shifting. Additionally, the frequency, duration and intensity of extreme weather events is increasing presenting severe challenges for the arrival, settlement and breeding success of arctic songbirds. Many questions arise such as how will these migrant birds cope with changing habitat and especially the occurrence of disruptive storms at arrival as well as during nesting? This project involved field and laboratory investigations of two arctic-breeding, migratory songbirds: the Lapland longspur, Calcarius lapponicus (LALO), a Holarctic distributed songbird, the Gambel’s white-crowned sparrow, Zonotrichia leucophrys gambelii (GWCS), a North American songbird breeding across the western USA and northern Canada. At least on the North Slope of Alaska, the breeding habitat for LALO appears to be shrinking, giving way to spreading shrub habitat favored by GWCS. We have conducted extensive investigations on the actions of the hypothalamo-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, especially corticosterone, in relation to coping with changing seasons, habitat and extreme weather events which can cause rapid increases in HPA axis activity. Hormonal profiles vary by year depending on ecological and environmental context and the responses to severe events were repeatable across years and are likely adaptive for helping organisms cope with a highly variable environment. We then explored how the HPA axis, and the target cell gene responses are modulated to enable flexibility in response to extreme weather events in all three populations, and the relationships with the hypothalamo-pituitary-gonad (HPG) axis and reproductive function. Evidence is growing that activation of the HPA axis can determine HPG function and particularly onset of nesting. The tundra specialist, LALO showed less flexibility to cope with a severe storm whereas GWCS with a broader range was able to weather the storm.

Broader impacts.  We have developed an educational and experiential program with the Student Landowner Education and Watershed Stewardship  (SLEWS) program located at the Audubon Farm and Nature Center, the center for land-based learning in Winters, CA. It is a multigenerational program that includes 1,500 school children, many from under represented populations in Sacramento, as well as local organic farms, Putah Creek Council (a local conservation group dedicated to restoration of wetlands in Yolo County, Ca), and the public.  A large focus of this program is to introduce students to ecological restoration as they are directed in clearing invasive species and garbage from local, creeks, streams and farms and planting indigenous plants that encourage wildlife habitation. 

During earlier grant funding L.M. Romero and P.I. J.C. Wingfield began writing a book on the comparative biology of stress and how animals cope with a changing world. It covers all the vertebrates. This was published in 2016 by Oxford University Press. The book was aimed at upper division undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty. It also is largely accessible to the informed lay reader. During the current grant period, P.I. Wingfield has been writing a second book on “environmental endocrinology: mechanisms for life cycles”. It is aimed at the same audience as the previous book and covers all vertebrates. The expected publisher is Springer Verlag Nature. The book brings together a vast literature on endocrine function in animals coping with the real world and what to expect with global change.
